newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Astra says gets FDA nod for Pulmicort Turbuhaler.
newsitem.headline: Astra says gets FDA nod for Pulmicort Turbuhaler.

text.p: Swedish drugs company Astra said on Tuesday that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) had approved its anti-asthma treatment, the Pulmicort Turbuhaler.
Astra said in a statement that the FDA had approved the treatment for long-term use by adults and for children aged six and over.
It would be introduced in the U.S. in the autumn of this year.
The clinical name for the drug is budesonide inhalation powder.
"Pulmicort Turbuhaler is the first corticosteroid dry powder inhaler for asthma to be approved in the United States," Astra said in a statement.
The drug company's patented Turbuhaler delivers the substance through an inhaler without the use of propellant gases like chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), Astra said.
Clinical tests show the device administers the drug more effectively than traditional aerosol inhalers, it said.
Astra CEO Hakan Mogren said the approval was a milestone for the company.

"Pulmicort has grown to become a leading anti-asthma drug in Europe, Australia and Canada. Our intention is to make Pulmicort a leading anti-asthma medication in the United States as well," Mogren said in the statement.
Pulmicort Turbuhaler is now approved in 64 countries. Sales in 1996 increased by 17 percent to 4.73 billion crowns, Astra said.
Astra shares have risen steadily in recent days amid market speculation that FDA approval was imminent.
Astra shares closed 1.5 crowns higher at 141 crowns on Tuesday.
